member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.CharacterWalkBaseHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Abstract packet handler for walk packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client movement requests. When a player clicks on the ground to move, the client sends a walk packet containing the current position and a series of directional steps to reach the target location. The server validates and executes the movement, notifying nearby players of position changes.

item.term: Packet size (6 for rotation-only, 6+ for movement with steps)
Packet type (0x1C, 0xD4, 0xD3, or 0x1D depending on version)
Target rotation (for rotation-only packet) or encoded path data

item.description: Full Walk (Length > 6): Player moves from source to target following encoded path
Rotation Only (Length = 6): Player rotates in place without moving

remarks.para:
Directional Step Encoding: Steps are encoded as 4-bit values (2 steps per byte), where each direction is:
0 = South (Down)
1 = SouthWest
2 = West (Left)
3 = NorthWest
4 = North (Up)
5 = NorthEast
6 = East (Right)
7 = SouthEast

item.description: Packet must be at least 6 bytes
Source coordinates must match or be near player's current position
All target tiles in path must be walkable (not blocked by terrain or objects)
Path must not exceed maximum walk distance in single packet
Player must not be in restricted state (stunned, frozen, dead)
Path must respect map boundaries

remarks.para: Success Response: Player position is updated and movement animation plays. Nearby players receive position update packets showing the movement.
Failure Response: If path is invalid, player position is corrected by sending current position back to client. Movement is rejected silently.

Version Differences:
0x1C (Season 6+): Latest walk packet format with extended features
0xD4 (0.97d): Intermediate version walk packet
0xD3 (0.75): Legacy walk packet with different encoding
0x1D: Alternative walk packet format
Different handlers (CharacterWalkHandlerPlugIn, WalkHandlerPlugIn095, etc.) implement version-specific decoding logic while sharing this base validation and execution.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.CharacterWalkBaseHandlerPlugIn.DecodePayload(MUnique.OpenMU.Network.Packets.ClientToServer.WalkRequest,MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.Direction@)
member.summary: Gets the walking directions from the walk packet and the final rotation of the character.
member.param: The walk request, received from the client.
The rotation of the character once the walking is done.
member.returns: The walking directions and the final rotation of the character.
member.remarks: We return here the directions left-rotated; I don't know yet if that's an error in our Direction-enum or just the client uses another enumeration for it.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.ChatMessageBaseHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Base class for a chat message handler.

item.term: Receiver Name (null-terminated, only used for whispers)
All players in visible range (~15 tiles)

item.description: Message length must not exceed maximum allowed characters (~60)
Player must not be muted or chat-banned
Player must not be in a restricted state (e.g., dead, trading)
For whispers: receiver name must be valid and player must be online
Rate limiting: prevents chat spam (configurable cooldown)
Message must not contain only whitespace
Message encoding: UTF-8 or ASCII depending on client version
Public Chat: Message broadcast to all nearby players via ShowMessagePlugIn
Whisper: Message sent to receiver via ShowMessagePlugIn, sender receives confirmation
Message includes sender name, message text, and chat type indicator

item.term: ShowMessagePlugIn with "[Receiver] is not online" message

item.description: Season 6+: Supports UTF-8 encoding for international characters
0.97d: ASCII encoding only, limited character set
0.75: ASCII encoding, no special character support
ChatMessageReceivedEvent: Published for all chat messages (logging, moderation)
Event includes sender, receiver, message text, timestamp, chat type
Can be used by plugins for: chat filtering, profanity detection, logging, bot detection

member.summary: Handler for guild create packets.

item.term: Guild Emblem (4x4 grid, 4 bits per pixel)

item.description: Level: Guild Master must be level 100+ (configurable)
Zen Cost: Typically 1,000,000 Zen (configurable)
Not In Guild: Player must not already be in a guild
Unique Name: Guild name must be unique on server
Name Format: 3-8 alphanumeric characters, no special symbols
Location: Must be near Guild Master NPC to create
Length: 3-8 characters
Allowed: Letters (A-Z, a-z) and numbers (0-9)
Not allowed: Spaces, special characters, profanity
Case-insensitive uniqueness check
Reserved names blocked (Admin, GM, etc.)
Size: 4x4 grid of pixels (16 pixels total)
Color Depth: 4 bits per pixel (16 colors from palette)
Data Size: 16 bytes (2 pixels per byte, packed)
Palette: Standard MU Online color palette
Displayed on guild member names and castle flags
Guild created in database with unique ID
Player assigned as Guild Master with full permissions
Zen cost deducted from player
Player receives ShowGuildCreateResultPlugIn (success message)
Guild emblem saved and visible to all players
Player's name displays with guild prefix

item.term: ShowMessagePlugIn: "You must be level 100 to create a guild."
ShowMessagePlugIn: "Not enough Zen to create guild."
ShowMessagePlugIn: "You are already in a guild."
ShowMessagePlugIn: "Guild name is already in use."

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Guild.GuildRequestHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handler for guild requests.

item.term: Guild Master Player ID (visible player object ID)

item.description: Step 1: Requestor targets Guild Master and sends join request (this handler)
Step 2: Guild Master receives join request dialog with requestor's name
Step 3: Guild Master accepts or declines (GuildRequestAnswerHandlerPlugIn)
Step 4: If accepted, requestor joins guild as regular member
Target player must be a Guild Master (not just any guild member)
Target Guild Master must be in visible range
Requestor must not already be in a guild
Guild must not be full (max members: typically 80)
Target player ID must be valid and online
Requestor cannot join their own guild (if they are Guild Master)
Guild Master receives ShowGuildJoinRequestPlugIn with requestor's name
Request dialog shows requestor character name and level
Guild Master has limited time to respond (~30 seconds)
Requestor waits for Guild Master's decision

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Items.ConsumeItemHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handler for item consume packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to consume (use) items from inventory. Consumable items include potions (HP/MP/SD recovery), scrolls (skill learning), jewels (item upgrading), fruits (stat modification), and other usable items.

item.term: Target item slot (for jewels/upgrade items, otherwise 0xFF)
Restore HP, MP, or SD immediately
Add or remove stat points based on fruit type

item.description: Item must exist in specified source slot
Item must be consumable (have ItemConsumeHandler registered)
Player must meet item requirements (level, class, stats)
For jewels: Target item must exist and be upgradeable
For scrolls: Player must not already know the skill
For fruits: Player must have stat points to modify
Cannot consume items during trade, PvP combat, or other restricted states
Some items have cooldowns between uses

remarks.para: Success Response: Item is consumed (removed or quantity decreased). Effect is applied (stat change, skill learned, item upgraded, etc.). Client receives success notification and updated stats/inventory.
Failure Response: Consumption fails and client receives error message with reason (requirements not met, upgrade failed, etc.).

item.description: AddPoints (0): Increase stat by fruit amount (e.g., +10 Strength)
RemovePoints (1): Decrease stat and refund level-up points

member.summary: Handler for item consume packets.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Items.DropItemHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handler for drop item packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to drop items from inventory onto the ground. Players can drop items by dragging them from inventory to the game world. The client specifies the inventory slot and target ground coordinates.

item.description: Item must exist in the specified inventory slot
Target coordinates must be within valid map bounds
Target location must be walkable (not blocked)
Target must be within drop range from player position
Some items cannot be dropped (quest items, bound items)
Player must not be in trade, shop, or other restricted state
Player must not be in a safe zone where dropping is prohibited

remarks.para: Success Response: Item is removed from inventory and spawned on ground at target location. Nearby players are notified of the new ground item.
Failure Response: Client receives failure message indicating why the drop was rejected.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Items.ItemMoveExtendedHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Packet handler for extended item move packets.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Items.ItemMoveHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handler for item move packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to move items between different storage areas. Players can move items within inventory, between inventory and vault, to/from trade windows, to/from chaos machine, and other item storage locations.

item.term: Packet size (variable, depends on item data)
Item data (serialized item, size varies by client version)

item.description: 0 - Inventory: Player's main item storage
1 - Trade: Item being offered in trade window
2 - Vault: Personal vault/warehouse storage
3 - Chaos Machine: Items placed in chaos machine for crafting
4 - Personal Shop: Items placed in personal shop
5 - Pet Inventory: Dark Raven or other pet storage
Source item must exist in specified source storage and slot
Target slot must have enough space for item dimensions
Storage transition must be valid (e.g., cannot move from trade to vault directly)
Player must have access to both source and target storage
Item must meet requirements for target storage (e.g., chaos machine item requirements)
Target slot must not be occupied by another item
Some operations are restricted during trade, combat, or other states

remarks.para: Success Response: Item is moved from source to target location. Client inventory is updated with new item positions.
Failure Response: Move is rejected and client receives failure notification. Item remains in original location.
Version Compatibility: This handler supports multiple client versions by dynamically determining item data size based on the client's ItemSerializer.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Items.PickupItemHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handler for item pickup packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to pick up items from the ground. When a player clicks on an item that is visible on the ground, the client sends a pickup request containing the item's server-assigned ID.

item.description: Item must exist on the current map
Item must be within pickup range (typically 3 tiles)
Player must have inventory space available
Item must not be owned by another player (drop protection)
Player must not be in a trade or shop state

remarks.para: Success Response: Item is added to inventory and removed from ground. Client receives item data packet and inventory update.
Failure Response: Client receives failure message with reason (inventory full, out of range, etc.).

Notification: All party members notified when someone is kicked
State Cleanup: Kicked player's party state reset immediately

Player index must be valid (0-4)
Target player must exist in party at that index
Cannot kick yourself (use party leave instead)

Party experience bonus deactivated

member.summary: Handler for talk npc request packets.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to interact with NPCs. When a player double-clicks or otherwise interacts with an NPC, the client sends this packet to initiate dialog or access NPC services (shop, vault, quest, etc.).

item.term: Opens NPC shop with buy/sell functionality
Opens personal vault for item storage
Shows quest information and accept/complete options
Opens pet training and evolution interface

item.description: NPC must exist on the current map with the specified ID
NPC must be within interaction range (typically 5 tiles)
Player must not be in combat, trade, or other restricted state
Player must meet NPC requirements (level, class, quest state)
Some NPCs are only accessible during specific events or times

remarks.para: Success Response: Server sends appropriate window opening packet based on NPC type. Client displays the corresponding UI (shop, vault, dialog, etc.).
Failure Response: If NPC is not found or player cannot interact, no response is sent or an error message is displayed.
Implementation Notes: This base class is inherited by version-specific handlers (TalkNpcHandlerPlugIn, TalkNpcHandlerPlugIn075) which differ only in encryption expectations.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.TargetedSkillHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Implements the targeted skill packet handler.

remarks.para: This handler processes client requests to use skills that target a specific entity. When a player uses a skill by clicking on a target (attack skills, buff skills, heal skills), the client sends this packet with the skill ID and target ID. The server validates requirements, calculates effects, and applies the skill to the target.

item.term: Skill ID (skill number from skill tree)
Power Slash, Cyclone, Death Stab, Flame Strike
Soul Barrier, Greater Defense, Bless, Swell Life
Summon Goblin, Summon Golem, Summon Monster

item.description: Player must know the skill (learned or innate)
Player must have sufficient mana/stamina/AG
Skill must not be on cooldown
Target must exist and be in range
Target must be valid for skill type (e.g., cannot attack allies, cannot heal enemies)
Player must meet skill requirements (level, stats, equipment)
Player must not be stunned, frozen, or in restricted state
For attack skills: Target must be attackable and not in safe zone
For buff skills: Target must be self or party member (class-dependent)

remarks.para: Success Response: Skill animation plays, effect is applied to target. Damage, healing, or status effects are calculated and applied. Mana/stamina is consumed. Cooldown timer starts. Nearby players see the skill animation.
Failure Response: Skill cast fails and client receives error message (not enough mana, target out of range, skill on cooldown, etc.).

Strategy Pattern: This handler uses a plugin-based strategy pattern where different skills can have custom implementations (ITargetedSkillPlugin). If no custom strategy exists, the default strategy handles standard targeting logic. This allows flexibility for special skills with unique mechanics.

item.description: Self: Player can target themselves (buffs, heals)
Party Member: Target is in same party (heals, buffs)
Monster: Target is a monster (attacks, debuffs)
Player (PvP): Target is another player (PvP combat)
NPC: Target is a summon or pet (commands)

member.remarks: In early versions, the index of the skill is used as identifier. Later it was the skill id. This may have changed earlier than season 2!.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeAcceptHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Packet Handler which is called when a trade request gets answered by the player.

item.term: Trade request cancelled, both players notified
Trade window opens for both players

item.description: Player must have a pending trade request
Trade partner must still be online and in range
Neither player can be in another trade
Response must arrive within timeout period (~30 seconds)
Both players must still meet trade requirements (not dead, not in vendor, etc.)
Both players receive ShowTradeWindowPlugIn to open trade interface
Trade state changes from TradeRequested to TradeOpened
Both players can now add items and money to the trade
Trade window displays empty slots for items and money input fields
Requester receives ShowMessagePlugIn: "[Player] declined the trade."
Trade state reset to None for both players
No trade window opens

item.term: Silently ignored or ShowMessagePlugIn: "No trade request pending."
ShowMessagePlugIn: "Trade partner is no longer available."

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeAcceptHandlerPlugIn.HandlePacketAsync(MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.Player,System.Memory{System.Byte})
member.summary: The packet looks like: 0xC1, 0x04, 0x37, 0x01.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeButtonHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handles the trade button packets.

item.term: Player pressed trade button (ready to complete)

item.description: Initial: Both buttons unchecked (Unchecked)
Player A Ready: Player A presses button (Checked), button turns yellow/gray
Player B Ready: Player B presses button (Checked)
Final Check (S6+): Both buttons turn red (Red state), requires final click
Completion: Trade executes when both in final confirmation
Reset: Any item/money change resets both buttons to Unchecked
Player must be in TradeOpened state
Items and money must not have changed since last button press
Both players must have enough inventory space for received items
Money transfer must not cause overflow for either player
Trade partner must still be online and in range
Items must still be valid and not expired/deleted
Both players receive TradeButtonStateChangePlugIn with updated button states
If only one ready: waiting for partner to press button
If both ready (pre-S6): trade completes immediately
If both ready (S6+): buttons turn red, require final confirmation
Items transferred atomically between players
Money transferred atomically between players
Both players receive TradeFinishedPlugIn notification
Trade window closes for both players
Inventory and money updated for both players
Trade state reset to None

item.term: ShowMessagePlugIn: "Not enough inventory space." + Trade cancelled
ShowMessagePlugIn: "Cannot receive that much money." + Trade cancelled
Button reset to Unchecked, ShowMessagePlugIn: "Trade items changed."

item.description: Pre-Season 6: Two-state button (Unchecked/Checked), completes immediately when both checked
Season 6+: Three-state button (Unchecked/Checked/Red), requires double confirmation
Red state provides extra protection against accidental trades

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeCancelHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handles the trade cancel packets.

item.description: Manual Cancel: Player clicks cancel button in trade window
Window Close: Player closes trade window via ESC or X button
Movement Cancel: Player moves too far from trade partner (>15 tiles)
State Change Cancel: Player enters invalid state (dies, enters vendor, etc.)
Timeout Cancel: Trade inactive for too long (auto-cancel after ~5 minutes)
Disconnect Cancel: Either player disconnects from server
Player must be in an active trade (TradeOpened or TradeButtonPressed state)
All items in trade window must be returned to original owners
Money amounts must be returned to original owners
Both players receive notification of cancellation
Both players receive TradeCancelledPlugIn notification
Trade window closes for both players
All items return to their original inventory slots
Money amounts restored to both players
Trade state reset to None for both players
Players can move and perform other actions again

item.term: Items dropped to ground or trade paused until space available

item.description: Distance between players exceeds 15 tiles
Either player dies or enters dead state
Either player opens NPC vendor window
Either player enters portal or warps to different map
Either player logs out or disconnects
Server shutdown or maintenance mode

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeMoneyHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handles the trade money packets.

item.description: Maximum Amount: 2,000,000,000 Zen per trade (uint max / 2)
Minimum Amount: 0 Zen (can trade items without money)
Real-time Updates: Money changes visible to both players immediately
Validation: Amount must not exceed player's current money balance
Button Reset: Changing money resets trade button to unpressed state
Player must be in TradeOpened state (trade window open)
Amount must not exceed player's current money (player.Money >= Amount)
Amount must be non-negative (>= 0)
Amount must not cause overflow when added to partner's money
Both players must have pressed trade button again after money change
Trade partner must still be in range and online
Both players receive TradeMoneySetPlugIn with updated amount
Money amount displayed in trade window for both players
If trade button was pressed, it resets to unpressed state
Both players must re-confirm trade after money change
Money not actually transferred until trade completion

item.term: ShowMessagePlugIn: "Money amount too large." + Trade cancelled
Silently clamped to 0 or trade cancelled

item.description: Money amounts locked when both players press trade button
Atomic transaction: both money transfers succeed or both fail
Player A money: (Current - OfferAmount + ReceiveAmount)
Player B money: (Current - OfferAmount + ReceiveAmount)
If either transfer would cause overflow, trade is cancelled

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.MessageHandler.Trade.TradeRequestHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: Handles the trade request packets.

item.term: Target Player ID (visible player's object ID)

item.description: Request Phase: Player A sends trade request to Player B (this handler)
Accept Phase: Player B accepts or rejects the request (TradeAcceptHandlerPlugIn)
Negotiation Phase: Both players add items and money (TradeMoneyHandlerPlugIn)
Confirmation Phase: Both players press trade button (TradeButtonHandlerPlugIn)
Completion Phase: Items and money exchanged, trade window closes
Cancel: Either player can cancel at any time (TradeCancelHandlerPlugIn)
Target player must be in visible range (~15 tiles)
Both players must not already be in a trade
Both players must not be in restricted states (dead, vendor window open, etc.)
Target player ID must be valid and correspond to an online player
Players cannot trade with themselves
Both players must be on the same map
Trade requests may have cooldown to prevent spam
Sender receives trade window open notification (waiting for partner response)
Target receives trade request dialog via ShowTradeRequestPlugIn
Target has limited time to accept/reject (~30 seconds timeout)
Both players' trade flags set to prevent duplicate trades

item.term: Trade request automatically canceled after timeout

item.description: None: No active trade
TradeRequested: Request sent, waiting for response
TradeOpened: Both accepted, trade window open
TradeButtonPressed: Player pressed trade button (ready to complete)
TradeFinished: Trade completed successfully
TradeCancelled: Trade cancelled by either player

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializer
member.summary: This item serializer is used to serialize the item data to the data packets. At the moment, each item is serialized into a 12-byte long part of an array: Byte Order: ItemCode Options Dura Exe Ancient Kind/380Opt HarmonyOpt Socket1 Socket2 Socket3 Socket4 Socket5.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializer075
member.summary: This item serializer is used to serialize the item data to the data packets for version 0.75. Each item is serialized into a 3-byte long part of an array.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializer095
member.summary: This item serializer is used to serialize the item data to the data packets for version 0.95. Each item is serialized into a 4-byte long part of an array.
member.remarks:
Bit pattern: Index Bits 0 gggn nnnn 1 slll lLoo 2 Durability 3 goxx xxxx
g = group n = number l = level L = luck s = skill o = option level x = exc option flags.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializerExtended
member.summary: This item serializer is used to serialize the item data to the data packets. At the moment, each item is serialized into a dynamical length 5 to 15-byte long part of an array.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializerExtended.ItemStruct
member.summary:
Layout: Group: 4 bit Number: 12 bit Level: 8 bit Dura: 8 bit OptFlags: 8 bit HasOpt HasLuck HasSkill HasExc HasAnc HasGuardian HasHarmony HasSockets Optional, depending on Flags: Opt_Lvl 4 bit Opt_Typ 4 bit Exc: 8 bit Anc_Dis 4 bit Anc_Bon 4 bit Harmony 8 bit Soc_Bon 4 bit Soc_Cnt 4 bit Sockets n * 8 bit
Total: 5 ~ 15 bytes.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializerExtended.ItemStruct.#ctor(System.Span{System.Byte})
member.summary:
Layout: Group: 4 bit Number: 12 bit Level: 8 bit Dura: 8 bit OptFlags: 8 bit HasOpt HasLuck HasSkill HasExc HasAnc HasGuardian HasHarmony HasSockets Optional, depending on Flags: Opt_Lvl 4 bit Opt_Typ 4 bit Exc: 8 bit Anc_Dis 4 bit Anc_Bon 4 bit Harmony 8 bit Soc_Bon 4 bit Soc_Cnt 4 bit Sockets n * 8 bit
Total: 5 ~ 15 bytes.

member.name: F:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ItemSerializerHelper.SocketOptionIndexOffsets
member.summary: The socket seed index offsets, where the key is the numerical value of a and the value is the first index of this corresponding elemental seed.
member.remarks: Webzen decided to put every possible socket option of each elemental seed type into one big list, which may contain up to elements. I couldn't figure out a pattern, but found these index offsets by trial and error. Their list contains holes, so expect that index 9 doesn't define an option.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.MasterSkillExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods regarding master skills.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.MasterSkillExtensions.GetMasterSkillIndex(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.Skill,MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Configuration.CharacterClass)
member.summary: Gets the index of the master skill on the clients master skill tree for the given character class.
member.returns: The index of the master skill on the clients master skill tree for the given character class.
member.remarks: Each possible visible slot of a master skill in the master skill tree is identified by an index. Each root has 36 slots (4 * 9), and roots are indexed one after another, that means left root starts at index 1, middle root at 37, right root at 73. As this display can differ between character classes, we have to pass it in here. To me, it's a mystery why Webzen can't work with the skill number alone and determine this index on client side. I decided to put this indexes into code since it would pollute the data model too much.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.ViewPlugInContainer
member.summary: A plugin container which selects plugin based on the provided version/season metadata.
member.remarks: Simplified example: View plugin container is meant for season 6. There are some IChatMessageViewPlugIns available for the seasons 1, 2, 6 and 7. Which one to choose? In this case, it's easy, we just select the one which is equal. Now, if we remove the plugin for season 6, so that 1, 2 and 7 are available? In this case, we assume that the last available season before the target season is the correct one, season 2.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameServer.RemoteView.World.ShowHitExtendedPlugIn.ShowHitAsync(MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.IAttackable,MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.HitInfo)
member.remarks: This Packet is sent to the Client when a Player or Monster got hit and damaged. It includes which Player/Monster got hit by who, and the Damage Type. It is obvious that the mu online protocol only supports 16 bits for each damage value. To prevent bugs (own player health) and to make it somehow visible that the damage exceeds 65k, we send more than one packet, if the 16bits are not enough.
